Lack of corroborating media reports or o: The expert's verdict mentions that there were no references to any corroborating media reports or official statements from the New York Police Department regarding the arrest of Xi Ping Chow. This raises doubts about the authenticity of the claim.
No record of arrest: trial, or incarceration: The expert's verdict states that no record could be found of an arrest, trial, or incarceration of anyone by the name of Xi Ping Chow in New York City in June 2017. This further undermines the credibility of the claim.
Inaccurate photo: The expert's verdict points out that the photo included in the article actually shows the June 2008 arrest of Victor Yau, a Queens man accused of assault. This discrepancy suggests that the article may be using misleading or unrelated visuals, casting doubt on the claim's authenticity.
Source: s history of fabricated stories: The expert's verdict highlights that the World News Daily Report, the source of the claim, has a long history of publishing entirely fabricated stories. This information raises concerns about the credibility and reliability of the source, further questioning the authenticity of the claim.
